How Do I Get Started?

In order to qualify as a Speaking Partner volunteer, you will need to complete the following steps:

  1. Complete the Preparation Materials. Use the information in the Preparation section to learn about what a Speaking Partner does and how to do it well.
  2. Complete the Assessment. When you’re finished reviewing the Preparation materials, you should take the assessment to make sure that you understand the important concepts and principles you’ve been learning. You must pass this assessment with at least 80% to qualify.
  3. Volunteer! Once you’ve successfully completed the assessment, a new page will automatically appear with a form on it. You must complete this form to confirm that you are completely qualified to volunteer. If there are no openings available at the time you register, we will contact you when one does become available.

Please note that it may take several weeks or even months before we have a need open up for new Speaking Partners. Generally, these will become available just before each new semester begins. (Information about semester start dates will be displayed in the box on the right, labeled “Upcoming Opportunities for Speaking Partners.”) Occasionally, they will open in the middle of a semester that’s already underway, but this is very rare.

What Do I Need?

  1. Internet -

    A Computer with a Reliable, Fast Internet Connection. This should be a DSL or cable internet connection, NOT a dial-up modem. If you’re not sure what kind of connection you have, contact your internet service provider (ISP).

  2. Skype -

    A Skype Account. Speaking Partners use Skype to communicate with their partners around the world. You will have to have a Skype account and be familiar with how to use the program. View Tutorials Here.

  3. Time -

    Some Time. You will need to have at least two hours a week to spend on this: one hour on Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, and one hour on Thursday, Friday, or Saturday. (We discourage Speaking Partners from doing their work on Sundays, even though it is not paid work.)

  4. Equipment -

    A Webcam and Microphone. These need to be connected to your computer. Most computers built since 2008 have built-in webcams; many also have built-in microphones. Either of these items can be purchased for relatively low prices from places like Walmart, Target, or Newegg.com.

  5. Optional -

    Headphones with an Attached Microphone. Although not necessary, these can help prevent feedback and echoes when using Skype.

New to Skype?

If you have never used Skype before, the following tutorials will help you download the program and get set up to start using it (opens in a new window): http://www.gcflearnfree.org/skype
